Subject: English
LanguageHeader: Some strategic language choices included language used to:

Subject: English
LanguageContent: Strategically characterise key stakeholders, for example, ‘obnoxiously loud’, ‘safe space’, ‘they offer’

Subject: English
LanguageContent: Encompass the community, but also distinguish between ‘lesser’ gyms, and to present collective responsibility through the use of pronouns and other strategies

Subject: English
LanguageContent: Appeal to the audience’s values, for example, ‘you have built your fitness’, ‘we are a community’, ‘they understand our’

Subject: English
LanguageContent: Highlight dichotomies, for example, ‘selfies on their socials’ versus ‘all bodies and all fitness journeys’

Subject: English
LanguageContent: Lighten the mood to imply the issue was not serious, for example, ‘worked together / worked out together’, ‘sweet delight to work with’

Subject: English
LanguageContent: Minimise the moral dilemma, for example, ‘uncomfortable’, ‘alternate funding’, ‘limited nutritional benefit’

Subject: English
LanguageContent: Escalate emotional responses, for example, ‘dire’, ‘bleak’, ‘closing … entirely’, ‘a carpark’, ‘be demolished!’, ‘lifeline’

Subject: English
LanguageContent: Reassure, for example, ‘guarantee’, ‘an opportunity’, ‘allow our imperfect community to flourish’

Subject: English
LanguageContent: Imply one option, for example, ‘only viable solution’, ‘a lifeline’, ‘we are voting for many’

Subject: English
LanguageContent: Reframe the dubious association, for example, lollies bring ‘joy’, ‘fun and laughter are … important … to health’, ‘our imperfect community’

Subject: English
LanguageContent: Pivot from the bleak to the optimistic, for example, ‘But we have found another option. A lifeline.’

Subject: English
LanguageHeader: Some strategic visual cues used in the images included:

Subject: English
LanguageContent: Giving a representation of gym members.

Subject: English
LanguageHeader: Students were not expected to laboriously identify and discuss every element. They were expected to select what was most pertinent to the persuasion to demonstrate their analytical capacity.

Subject: English
LanguageHeader: Students were also invited to discuss the interplay between argument, language and visual elements of the text.
